bestBHT.bht: Give your gifts willingly and joyfully, not reluctantly out of grief or necessity. God does not love those who give begrudgingly; rather, He loves a cheerful giver. Let your giving be purposeful and intentional, reflecting God's own generous nature. When you give, do it with a glad heart, not out of sorrow. Remember, God blesses those who give cheerfully and generously. May your generosity be marked by a joyful attitude, for God values the cheerful obedience and generosity of His children.

Henry Alford: Let the full consent of the free will go with the gift; let it not be a reluctant offering, given out of grief (so literally), out of an annoyed and troubled mind at having the gift extorted.
Nor out of necessity, because compelled.
Such givers, that is implied, God does not love.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Let the full consent of the free will go with the gift.
Opposed to 'of necessity,' as 'grudgingly' is opposed to 'a cheerful giver'.
Albert Barnes: The main idea in this verse is, that the act of giving should be voluntary and cheerful.
We should follow the dictates of the heart in giving.
God loves it because it shows a heart like his own - a heart disposed to give cheerfully and do good on the largest scale possible.
Marvin Vincent: Purposeth [προαιρειται] . Read prohrhtai, perfect tense, hath purposed.
Grudgingly [εκ λυπης] . Lit., out of sorrow.
Cheerful [ιλαρον] . Only here in the New Testament.
John Calvin: Liberality is estimated by God, not so much from the sum, as from the disposition.
He intimates that, on the other hand, the niggardly and reluctant are loathed by Him.
He requires from us the cheerful obedience of children.
Philip Schaff: Let each man do according as he hath purposed in his heart; not grudgingly (Gr. ‘of grief’ or ‘sorrow’ as being wrung from him, and pained to think of the sacrifice he has to make)."
For God loveth a cheerful giver."
On the bearing of this on the tithe principle supposed by some to be obligatory on Christians see on 1 Corinthians 16:0, notes (2) and (3).
Archibald T. Robertson: Not grudgingly...Not give as out of sorrow.
For God loveth a cheerful giver...Our word 'hilarious' comes from ιλαρον which is from ιλαος (propitious), an old and common adjective, only here in N.T.
John Gill: Every man according as he purposeth in his heart...so let him give...not grudgingly...or of necessity.
God blesses a cheerful man, and a giver.
John Wesley: Of necessity — Because he cannot tell how to refuse.

bhtAttempts.bht: Let your giving be a voluntary and joyful act, not compelled or reluctant out of grief or necessity. God does not love those who give begrudgingly. Instead, give with a cheerful heart and a purposeful intention. God has purposed us to be joyful and generous givers. Don't give out of sorrow, but rather out of a spirit of gladness. For God loves those who give with a cheerful heart, reflecting His own propitious and generous nature. May your liberality be marked not by the amount, but by the disposition of your heart, as God values the cheerful obedience and generosity of His children.

Let your giving be voluntary and joyful, not compelled or reluctant. God does not love those who give begrudgingly. Instead, give with a cheerful heart and a purposeful intention. God has purposed us to be joyful and generous givers. Don't give out of sorrow, but rather out of gladness. For God loves those who give with a cheerful heart, reflecting His own generous nature. May your liberality be marked by the disposition of your heart, as God values the cheerful obedience of His children.

When it comes to giving, let it be a voluntary and cheerful act, not driven by compulsion or reluctance. God's love is not for those who give grudgingly. Instead, give with a purposeful heart, as God has purposed us to be joyful and generous givers. Avoid giving out of sorrow; rather, give with a spirit of gladness. Remember, God loves those who give with a cheerful heart, reflecting His own generous nature. May your generosity be marked by a joyful disposition, for God values the cheerful obedience of His children.

Give your gifts willingly and with joy, not out of compulsion or reluctance. God does not favor those who give grudgingly. Let your giving come from a purposeful heart, for God has purposed us to be joyful and generous. Avoid giving out of sorrow, but instead give with a spirit of gladness. Remember, God loves those who give cheerfully, reflecting His own generous nature. In your generosity, let your cheerful disposition shine, for God values the joyful obedience of His children.

Give your gifts willingly and joyfully, not reluctantly out of grief or necessity. God does not love those who give begrudgingly; rather, He loves a cheerful giver. Let your giving be purposeful and intentional, reflecting God's own generous nature. When you give, do it with a glad heart, not out of sorrow. Remember, God blesses those who give cheerfully and generously. May your generosity be marked by a joyful attitude, for God values the cheerful obedience and generosity of His children.
